awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Statistical Learning, Driving Simulator-Based Modeling, and Computationally Tractable Dynamic Traffic Assignment
awd_abstract_narration:
Congestion is familiar to anyone who relies on a privately owned or rented automobile, taxi, or public transit for commuting, shopping and errand running. Historically, engineers and scientists exploring traffic networks frequently build mathematical models with the intent of coaxing from them insights revealing how congestion may evolve over time. Unfortunately, such models may easily become so large and complex that they are unwieldly, and simplifications are needed in order to provide passengers and drivers with accurate and rapidly computable information pertinent to route choice and departure time selection. Toward that goal, this project will employ modern statistics, simulation experiments, and notions of competition among traffic network users for available road capacity to better depict and more efficiently compute the behaviors of drivers who rely on road networks. The broader impacts of this research will be substantial. In particular, the results of this research will allow commuters and urban freight carriers to make more informed travel decisions, and governmental organizations to better regulate travel decisions within heavily congested major metropolitan regions. This study will also provide system-level experiential learning opportunities for students entering the transportation workforce. 

Specifically, through a combination of experiments and machine learning and model development, this project will aim to depict the noncooperative exploration of available routes and departure times by drivers and passengers seeking to fulfill their travel demands via metropolitan road networks. A key goal of the intended research will be the efficient computation of solutions to the most prevalent type of dynamic traffic assignment (DTA), namely so-called dynamic user equilibrium (DUE). It is the lack of closed-form travel-delay operators that makes DUE computation tedious and slow. The plan is to replace the existing, differential algebraic equation (DAE) system representing travel delay with closed-form, approximate delay operators based on a form of statistical learning known as Kriging. Ad hoc experiments based on such an approach show great promise for small networks, but are not definitive. The PIs will develop the envisioned models and make developed software available as free-ware or inexpensive apps.

por.por_cntn:
Introduction

Advances in information and communications technologies enable travelers to make more informed decisions based on real-time traffic information, as opposed to merely relying on prior experience. Real-time travel information from multiple sources allows travelers to update their route choice by the provision of en-route information that is based on dynamic traffic conditions. However, the effects of information provision on route choice behavior are not sufficiently clear. Most existing route choice models lack the ability to consider the latent cognitive effects of information on drivers and their impacts on route choice decisions. The investigation of route choice behavior under information provision can be leveraged by traffic operators to design information content and its delivery systems for managing network-wide traffic. However, despite substantial efforts in developing models to address various dimensions and characteristics associated with travelers’ route choice decision-making, challenges persist in data collection burden and lack of model transferability. Developing transferable route choice models enables leveraging route choice data under different scenarios to model route choice behavior consistently and mitigate the data collection burden.

In this project, driving simulator experiments were conducted to understand the relationship between drivers’ physiological responses and their cognitive state and route choice under dynamic traffic information provision. The driving simulator experiments were designed to elicit realistic route choices using a network-level setup featuring routes with different characteristics (in terms of travel time and driving environment complexity) and dynamic ambient traffic. Averaged EEG (electroencephalogram) band powers in multiple brain regions were used to extract two latent cognitive variables that capture driver’s cognitive effort during and immediately after the information provision, and cognitive inattention before implementing the route choice decision. A Multiple Indicators Multiple Causes model wass used to test the effects of several explanatory factors on the latent cognitive variables, and their combined impacts on route choice decisions. A transferable route choice model was developed based on a graph neural network (GNN). This GNN-based route choice (GNN-RC) model uses a connected graph, which encodes information of route alternatives as node features in the graph, as an input. The correlations among alternatives are characterized by the graph edge weights and captured through graph diffusion embedding. Related route choice experiments that entail richer route choice scenarios were conducted with drivers as participants in a high-fidelity full-cab driving simulator at Georgia Tech’s ACT Lab. In these experiments, participants drove four trips in a network, with different scenarios in terms of the number of alternative routes and the route correlations. The data collected was used to calibrate the proposed GNN-RC model and validate its transferability.

Findings

The key findings of this projects are as follows: (i) drivers who are more attentive and exert more cognitive effort are more likely to switch from their current route by complying with the information provided; (ii) drivers are more likely to switch routes if they receive descriptive travel time information or information indicating downstream congestion on the current route; (iii) certain driver attributes (e.g., gender) affect drivers’ route choices indirectly through latent information-induced cognitive effects, providing opportunities for information service providers and traffic operators to collaborate for designing and disseminating personalized information based on driver attributes to achieve their objectives; (iv) the proposed GNN-RC model yields high transferability levels for different scenarios when the underlying decision-making process is consistent, (v) the calibration process demonstrates how transferability can reduce data collection burden, enhancing the application range of the calibrated route choice model, and (vi) the proposed GNN-RC model can capture route correlations resulting from overlaps, especially when the correlations are complex and entail large number of alternatives.
